name: acknowledge
description: Acknowledgments are explicit utterances consisting of short phrases such as “ok”, “yes”, “uh-huh”, that signal that the previous utterance was understood without necessarily signaling acceptance. They do not resolve the content of the utterance they address.
implication: The listener has heard the message and is ready to continue, but no commitment to acceptance or resolution has been made; you may proceed but should still verify any critical details before moving on.

name: signal_understanding
description: An utterance that signals understanding explicitly.
implication: The listener comprehends the content and you can safely build on it or advance to the next point without further clarification.

name: signal_partial_understanding
description: An utterance which explicitly signals partial understanding.
implication: The listener grasps some aspects but remains unclear on others; you should identify and clarify the ambiguous parts before proceeding.

name: signal_non_understanding
description: An utterance that explicitly signals that the speaker has not understood the previous utterance.
example: Examples: 'I don’t understand', 'What did you say?', 'What do you mean by that?'
implication: The listener has failed to comprehend; you must rephrase, elaborate, or provide additional context to ensure understanding.

name: completion
description: An utterance that shows understanding by finishing or adding to the clause that a speaker is in the middle of constructing.
implication: The listener is actively engaged and sufficiently understands the ongoing content; you can invite further collaboration or confirmation and build on their contribution.

name: non_lexical_backchannel
description: A vocalized sound that has little or no referential meaning but still verbalizes the listener's attention.
implication: The listener is attending but the level of comprehension is uncertain; you may continue but remain alert for more explicit signals or prompt for clarification if needed.
